Antecedents of attribution-dependent affect include goal relevance and affective expectations. Consequences of attribution-dependent affect include spectators' satisfaction with the quality of the performance and their perceptions of its entertainment value. Performance satisfaction and goal relevance predict optimism about the team's chances in future games. The model is applied to data collected from 228 student participants watching conference basketball games involving their school's men's team on television, who reported their affective expectations and emotions during the game. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Madrigal, Robert

title: Attitude formation through exploration: Valence asymmetries.
abstract: The formation of attitudes toward novel objects was examined as a function of exploratory behavior. An initial experiment, in which participants played a computer game that required them to learn which stimuli, when sampled, produced favorable or unfavorable outcomes, demonstrated learning, attitude formation, and generalization to novel objects. The findings also revealed 2 interesting valence asymmetries: a learning asymmetry involving better learning for negatively valenced than positively valenced objects and a generalization asymmetry involving stronger generalization as a function of negative than of positive attitudes. Findings from 4 experiments led to an explanation of the learning asymmetry in terms of information gain being contingent on approach behavior and related the generalization asymmetry to a negativity bias that weighs resemblance to a known negative more heavily than resemblance to a positive. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
authors: Fazio, Russell H.; Eiser, J. Richard; Shook, Natalie J.

title: The Abstracts of the 39th Conference of The Australian Psychological Society.
abstract: Presents a collection of abstracts on personality psychology. One of the articles is: 'Performance-based measurement of aggression in a computer game-embedded simulation,' by E.V. Aidman. This article examines effects of aggression-inducing instruction on various game simulation measures. Another article 'Men suffering masculinity: Self-esteem and gender role stress vulnerability in middle-aged men with relationship problems,' by G. Egan and E.V. Aidman. This study examined the relationships between masculinity, self-esteem, emotional distress and gender role stress (GRS) in a self-selected group of middle-aged men who chose to participate in a relationship problems (RP) support group. Another article 'Efficacy of Internet-based cognitive behavior therapy for panic disorder and agoraphobia,' by M.E. Alvarenga, J.C. Richards and B. Klein. This paper discusses the evaluation of our internet-based, structured cognitive behavioral treatment for panic disorder and agoraphobia. Another article 'Adolescent engagement with problem-solving tasks: The role of coping strategies and positive emotions,' by M.J. Andrews. This paper examines student coping strategies, positive emotions, and learning during engagement with authentic, real-world problems. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Katsikitis, Mary

title: Might virtual reality promote the mood benefits of exercise?
abstract: This study sought to investigate if virtual reality technology enhances the psychological benefits of aerobic exercise in a laboratory setting. In this study, 88 university faculty and staff (44 females, 44 males) were randomly assigned to one of three 30-min conditions including: (1) bicycling at a moderate intensity (60-70% maximum heart rate) on a stationary bicycle, (2) playing a virtual reality computer bicycle game, or (3) an interactive virtual reality bicycle experience on a computer while exercising on a stationary bike at moderate intensity (60-70% maximum heart rate). The Activation-Deactivation Adjective Check List (AD-ACL) was administered immediately before and after the laboratory session. Results suggest that virtual reality enhances some of the mood benefits when paired with exercise. Virtual reality when paired with exercise enhances enjoyment, energy, and reduces tiredness. Virtual reality without exercise was discovered to increase participants' tension, tiredness, and lower their energy level. Results suggest that the combination of virtual reality and exercise might improve some of the beneficial psychological effects of exercise compared with virtual reality or exercise alone. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Plante, Thomas G.; Aldridge, Arianne; Bogden, Ryan; Hanelin, Cara

title: Gerontechnology in France.
abstract: The institutional context for gerontechnology development in France is improving. Still a number of obstacles remain before rapid mainstreaming of products and services in mass markets can take place. Some service providers are working on Telehealth service platforms with a 24/24 medical service. Many innovative products and services are proposed to local authorities who support autonomy and care for the home dwelling frail or disabled elderly persons: wearable geo-localizers, transmission of vital signs, emergency situations detecting devices for support, video interactive communication connected to touch-screen computers or TV-video games are used successfully in nursing homes for entertainment and cognitive stimulation. A catalogue assessing the use, reliability and availability of the gerontechnological devices is required. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Cornet, G.; Rumeau, P.

title: Anxiety and presence during VR immersion: A comparative study of the reactions of phobic and non-phobic participants in therapeutic virtual environments derived from computer games.
abstract: Virtual reality can be used to provide phobic clients with therapeutic exposure to phobogenic stimuli. However, purpose-built therapeutic VR hardware and software can be expensive and difficult to adapt to individual client needs. In this study, inexpensive and readily adaptable PC computer games were used to provide exposure therapy to 13 phobic participants and 13 non-phobic control participants. It was found that anxiety could be induced in phobic participants by exposing them to phobogenic stimuli in therapeutic virtual environments derived from computer games (TVEDG). Assessments were made of the impact of simulator sickness and of sense of presence on the phobogenic effectiveness of TVEDGs. Participants reported low levels of simulator sickness, and the results indicate that simulator sickness had no significant impact on either anxiety or sense of presence. Group differences, correlations, and regression analyses indicate a synergistic relationship between presence and anxiety. These results do not support Slater's¹ contention that presence and emotion are orthogonal. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Robillard, Geneviève; Bouchard, Stéphane; Fournier, Thomas; Renaud, Patrice

title: SenToy: An affective sympathetic interface.
abstract: We describe the design and implementation of SenToy, a tangible doll with sensors that allows a user to influence the emotions of a synthetic character in a game. SenToy is an input device that allows the user to perform gestures or movements that the sensors inside the doll pick up. The gestures are interpreted according to a scheme found through two different user studies: one Wizard of Oz study and one study with a fully functioning SenToy. Different gestures express one of the following emotions: anger, fear, surprise, sadness, gloating and happiness. Depending upon the expressed emotion, the synthetic character in the game will, in turn, perform different actions (trading, duelling, etc.). The evaluation of SenToy acting as the interface to the computer game FantasyA has shown that the users were able to express the desired emotions to influence the synthetic characters, and that overall players liked the doll as an interface. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Paiva, Ana; Costa, Marco; Chaves, Ricardo; Piedade, Moisés; Mourão, Dário; Sobral, Daniel; Höök, Kristina; Andersson, Gerd; Bullock, Adrian

title: Leisure time activities of elementary school children.
abstract: The 3 most common leisure time activities reported by 2,200 3rd and 4th grade children (aged 7–12 yrs) and the association of the intensity levels of those activities with demographic variables and risk factors for cardiovascular disease are presented. Activities reported most often by boys were playing video games (33%), playing football (32%), bicycling (31%), watching television (28%), and playing basketball (26%). The girls reported doing homework (39%), bicycling (31%), watching television (30%), dancing (27%), and reading (23%). The average metabolic equivalent was 4.2 for girls and 4.8 for boys. Among boys, African Americans reported more vigorous activities whereas White girls reported somewhat more vigorous activities than those reported by non-White girls. A higher socioeconomic status, was associated with a greater proportion of sedentary activities. The risk factors of cholesterol, blood pressure, skinfold thickness, and body mass index were not significantly associated with total activity score. However, significantly more nonobese than obese children reported a vigorous (high-intensity) activity as one of their top 3 activities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Harrell, Joanne S.; Gansky, Stuart A.; Bradley, Chyrise B.; McMurray, Robert G.

title: Hostilidad, patrón de conducta tipo A y reactividad cardiaca. = Hostility, type A behavioral pattern and cardiac reactivity of Type A/B subjects.
abstract: Examines self-reported hostility and cardiac reactivity of Type A and Type B Ss. Forty male students (median age 22.4 yrs) from 4 groups (Type A, high hostility; Type A, low hostility; Type B, high hostility; Type B, low hostility) underwent 3 tests: mental arithmetic, competitive video game and cardiac defense response to high intense auditory stimulation. Results showed no differences in heart rate reactivity between Type A and Type B Ss with high self-reported hostility but differences between Type A and Type B Ss with low hostility. Type A Ss increased heart rate during habituation of the cardiac defense response and competitive video game. Denial or suppression of hostility in Type A Ss may be associated with increased cardiovascular reactivity. (Spanish abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Robles Ortega, H.; Marfil, N.; Reyes del Paso, G.

title: Cardiovascular reactivity in anger-defensive individuals: The influence of task demands.
abstract: Examined whether elevated cardiovascular response to stressful stimuli for individuals who are defensive in their reporting of anger might be moderated by the demands of the stressor task. 40 male undergraduates were exposed to 4 tasks: shock avoidance video game, handgrip, film, and cold pressor. Defensive/low anger Ss exhibited elevated heart rate and systolic blood pressure responses as compared with other Ss, but only to the shock avoidance task. Defensive/low anger Ss also reported less state anger to all tasks. It is proposed that an anger defensive style results in elevated cardiovascular activity only in interaction with stressors that elicit a sympathetic nervous system response and/or involve evaluation threat. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Miller, Sydney B.

title: Die Evolution von Fairnessnormen im Ultimatumspiel: Eine spieltheoretische Modellierung. = The Evolution of Norms of Fairness in the Ultimatum Game: A Game Theoretical Model.
abstract: The ultimatum game describes a social bargaining situation in which considerations of fairness become relevant. At first sight, experimental research seems to contradict game theoretical predictions: The majority of proposals are aimed at equal division, and responders are willing to refuse offers that are perceived as too low. In order to explain fair behavior (and morality in general), non-material incentives are also important. In this article, a new evolutionary model of fairness is presented that explains the rejection of positive offers. I follow Frank's (1992) approach, in which emotions, if perceived, are recognized as rendering the threat of sanctions creditable. Furthermore, the idea of inspection costs is combined with the noise level suggested by Binmore and Samuelson (1994). Computer simulations demonstrate the evolution of norms of fairness: It is beneficial for responders to refuse low offers because this raises the share offered. As a result, this model explains orientations toward fairness as an outcome of evolutionary forces which themselves are due to individual self-interest. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Vieth, Manuela

title: Gesundheitsverhalten von Grundschulkindern: Geschlechtsunterschiede und die Bedeutung der defensiven Emotionsregulation. = Health behavior of primary school students: Gender differences and the meaning of defensive emotion regulation.
abstract: Examined whether gender differences in health behavior can be explained by gender differences in avoidant emotion regulation. For 248 primary school students avoidant emotion regulation, health behavior, and Body Mass Index were assessed. Children's self report data were validated with their mother's ratings. Additionally, the number of days the children missed school because of illness was assessed (mother's perspective). The results indicate that girls take better care of their oral hygiene, act more carefully in traffic situations, eat healthier food, and are less interested in sports as well as in watching TV and in playing computer games. Furthermore, they sleep longer and avoid dangerous games. While gender differences in physical exercise and in playing dangerous games are due to boys' higher scores in avoidant regulation, boys who score low in avoidant regulation play computer games more frequently. These non defensive boys were highest in relative body weight but missed school less often. Considering the results, the costs and benefits of avoidant emotion regulation for health behavior are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Mohiyeddini, Changiz; Kohlmann, Carl-Walter

title: Negative feelings exacerbate hostile attibutions of intent in highly aggressive boys.
abstract: Tested the hypothesis that aggressive boys' tendency to attribute hostile intentions to peers is exacerbated in a negative emotional state. 29 highly aggressive boys in special education for aggressive behavior problems, 12 moderately aggressive boys in regular education, and 16 nonaggressive boys in regular education (all subjects aged 9-13 yrs) inferred peers' intentions in 8 vignettes concerning ambiguous provocation by peers. Mild negative emotions were induced by unjust loss of a manipulated computer game. Half the vignettes were completed in this negative emotional state. After completion of all vignettes, the game was played again and won to reinduce positive feelings. Self-ratings of feelings obtained throughout the study show that the manipulations consecutively induced negative and positive feelings. Negative feelings increased hostile attribution of intent in the highly aggressive group. Highly and moderately aggressive boys responded more aggressively than nonaggressive boys. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Journal of Clinical Child and Adolescent Psychology
authors: de Castro, Bram Orobio; Slot, Nico W.; Bosch, Joop D.; Koops, Willem; Veerman, Jan W.

title: Respiratory changes during detection of deception: Mechanisms underlying inhibitory breathing in response to critical questions.
abstract: The present study was designed to compare respiratory changes during the detection of guilty knowledge test in a mock crime situation with respiratory changes during laboratory stressors. Sixteen male and fourteen female undergraduates participated in the following five sessions: pre-trial rest (PR), mental arithmetic (MA), a video game(VG), detection of deception (DD), and post-trial rest (PO). Of the respiratory control indices, respiratory drive (mean inspiratory flow rate) significantly increased during MA and VG, whereas respiratory timing (inspiratory time / breath time) did not show any consistent changes during either stressors. In contrast, the index of respiratory drive did not show any significant increments in response to critical items in the guilty knowledge test in the DD condition, in which each subjects were required to commit a mock theft. Decrements in expiratory volume and minute ventilation in response to critical items were significantly greater than those in response to non-critical items. These results suggested that respiration during stress tends to be hyperventilated, and also suggested that respiration during deception is characterized by inhibitory breathing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Japanese Journal of Physiological Psychology and Psychophysiology
authors: Kurohara, Akira; Terai, Kensuke; Takeuchi, Hiromi; Umezawa, Akio

title: Diminished pulse pressure response to psychological stress: Early precursor of essential hypertension?
abstract: An excessive blood pressure (BP) response to mental stress is a widely reported characteristic of young normotensive offspring of hypertensive parents. At odds with these reports are data from a large biracial study (C. K. Ewart et al; see record [rid]1988-04840-001[/rid]) showing that high risk adolescent offspring had diminished pulse pressure under mental stress and no evidence of greater BP reactivity. This apparent contradiction was examined in a similar but larger sample of 186 Black and 86 White normotensive adolescents (aged 14–15 yrs) comparing BP and heart rate responses to video game, mirror drawing, mental arithmetic, interview, and physical exercise in high- and low-risk offspring. Results replicated the diminished pulse pressure finding, suggesting that it is characteristic of African Americans and is evoked by behavioral tasks that entail skeletal-motor inhibition. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Ewart, Craig K.; Kolodner, Kenneth B.

title: Relationships among socioeconomic status, stress induced changes in cortisol, and blood pressure in African American males.
abstract: Notes that the inverse relation between socioeconomic status (SES) and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk has been posited to be partially due to exaggerated cardiovascular reactivity (CVR) to stress. Stress elicits hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis activation (e.g., increased cortisol secretion), which may contribute to subsequent blood pressure (BP) elevation. The present study assessed univariate associations among SES, cortisol secretion, and aggregated change scores to stressors (i.e., video game and forehead cold) for systolic BP (SBP) and diastolic BP (DBP) in a sample of 24 African American males (aged 16-25 yrs). Circadian variability of cortisol level was taken into account by partialling out collection time. Family SES was inversely related to initial cortisol level. Neighborhood SES was inversely related to DBP reactivity. The change in cortisol level during the stressor protocol was related to SBP reactivity. These results suggest that SES may be linked to CVD via BP and cortisol reactivity to stress, but prospective studies are needed to clarify whether such is the case. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Kapuku, Gaston K.; Treiber, Frank A.; Davis, Harry C.

title: Modulation of attentional inhibition by norepinephrine and cortisol after psychological stress.
abstract: Examined the effects of mild psychological stress on selective attention, as assessed by the negative priming (NP) paradigm. Salivary measures of the stress hormone cortisol (CORT) and α-amylase (a correlate of norepinephrine [NE]) were assayed to probe the relationship between the stress response and attentional inhibition. 20 healthy Ss (aged 18–24 yrs) engaged in the attention task, which was then followed by 15 min of a stressful video game before a return to the attentional task. Baseline saliva samples were obtained before the experiment began, 1 min after the video-game stressor, and 20 min post-stress. Ss showed a significant reduction in NP and a decrease in reaction time (RT) after the video game. Moreover, α-amylase levels increased significantly after the stressor, indicating the role of NE in the acute stress response. While CORT levels remained unchanged after stress, CORT correlated significantly with both NP scores and RT after the stressor. These results imply that mild psychological stress can significantly alter attentional processes. Given the increase in α-amylase and the correlation between attention and CORT after stress, it seems likely that attentional processes are under tight control by brain systems which mediate the fight-or-flight response. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Skosnik, Patrick D.; Chatterton, Robert T. Jr.; Swisher, Tara; Park, Sohee

title: Ecocultural understanding of children's developmental pathways.
abstract: Every cultural community provides developmental pathways for children within some ecological-cultural (ecocultural) context. Cultural pathways are made up of everyday routines of life, and routines are made up of cultural activities children engage. Activities (bedtime, playing video games, homework, watching TV, cooking dinner, soccer practice, visiting grandma, babysitting for money, algebra class) are useful units for cultural analysis because they are meaningful units for parents and children, and they are amenable to ethnographic fieldwork, systemic observation, and interviewing. Activities crystallize culture directly in everyday experience, because they include values and goals, resources needed to make the activity happen, people in relationships, the tasks the activity is there to accomplish, emotions and motives of those engaged in the activity, and a script defining the appropriate, normative way to engage in that activity. The Ecocultural Family Interview provides a window into children's and families' daily routines and activities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Weisner, Thomas S.

title: Hot temperatures, hostile affect, hostile cognition, and arousal: Tests of a general model of affective aggression.
abstract: Used a general model of affective aggression to generate predictions concerning hot temperatures (HTs). Exp 1 examined HT effects on hostile affect, hostile cognition, perceived arousal, and physiological arousal with 107 undergraduates who played video games while room temperature was controlled. Exp 2 examined HT effects on hostile affect, perceived and physiological arousal, and general positive and negative affect with 43 undergraduates who performed brief aerobic exercise. HTs increased hostile affect, hostile cognition, and physiological arousal, and decreased perceived arousal and general positive affect. Results suggest that HTs may increase aggressive tendencies by 3 separate routes. Hostile affect, hostile cognitions, and excitation transfer processes may increase the likelihood of biased appraisals of ambiguous social events, biased in a hostile direction. The usefulness of the general model was supported. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Anderson, Craig A.; Deuser, William E.; DeNeve, Kristina M.

title: Cardiovascular reactivity in Black and White siblings versus matched controls.
abstract: Examined racial differences in cardiovascular (CV) reactivity in 128 healthy Black and White siblings (average age 13 yrs). Ss included 15 pairs of Black siblings and their age- and sex-matched unrelated controls and 17 pairs of White siblings and their age- and sex-matched unrelated controls. Systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), and heart rate (HR) measurements were obtained at rest and during a stress task (competitive video game). Black Ss demonstrated a significantly higher intraclass correlation for DBP reactivity than Black controls or White Ss. Black Ss demonstrated a steeper rise and then a plateau in DBP and HR reactivity to the video game task, while White Ss showed a more gradual increase in these measures over the course of playing 3 video games. Results suggest a stronger genetic influence of CV reactivity in Black than in White children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Wilson, Dawn K.; Holmes, Samantha D.; Arheart, Kristopher; Alpert, Bruce S.

title: Estradiol, progesterone and cardiovascular response to stress.
abstract: Examined the relationship between endogenous estradiol and progesterone levels and cardiovascular activity at rest and during stress in 44 female undergraduates. Ss were tested in both the follicular and luteal phases of the menstrual cycle. During the luteal phase, higher levels of estradiol were associated with lower levels of cardiac output responses to the combined video game and speech tasks, and lower levels of heart rate and systolic BP responses to the cold pressor. Also, higher levels of progesterone were associated with higher total peripheral resistance and lower stroke volume responses to the cold pressor. During the follicular phase, higher levels of progesterone were associated with lower vascular resistance responses to the cold pressor. Results suggest that estradiol may contribute to a lowering of cardiovascular responses to stress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Sita, Aurelio; Miller, Sydney B.

title: The relationship between learning style and cognitive style.
abstract: Explored the construct validity of learning style as operationalised in the Learning Styles Inventory (LSI) and its relationship with cognitive style as measured using the Cognitive Styles Analysis (CSA). In addition, the relationship between styles and learning preferences were examined. Ss were 107 male and female university students (aged 19–55 yrs) who completed the LSI and CSA. Ss also completed learning preferences measures which consisted of a list of teaching and learning methods to which Ss had been exposed during the normal course of their studies. The 3 groups of methods that were distinguished included autonomous methods (open/distance/flexible learning and computer-assisted learning), collaborative methods (role play, group work, and games and simulations), and dependent methods (tutorial/surgery and lecture). The results suggest that the LSI assesses 2 dimensions (comprehension and transformation). Further, learning style and cognitive style appear to be independent. The relationship between style and preference is mediated by gender. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Sadler-Smith, Eugene

title: Effects of race, sex, and socioeconomic status upon cardiovascular stress responsivity and recovery in youth.
abstract: Cardiovascular responsivity to and recovery from acute laboratory stressors, as derived from aggregate scores of cardiovascular functioning during and after postural change, video game challenge, social competence interview, and parent–child conflict discussion, were evaluated in 272 Black and White youths (mean age 13.5 yrs) with a positive family history of essential hypertension. Results show that Blacks demonstrated greater systolic and diastolic BP and lower heart rate responsivity vs Whites. A race by neighborhood SES interaction for systolic BP responsivity was also observed where low SES Whites and high SES Blacks had the greatest responsivity vs their same race cohorts. Upper SES Whites had the lowest total peripheral resistance responsivity. For recovery, Blacks and males exhibited higher systolic BP during recovery vs Whites and females, respectively. These findings extend previous studies and provide further support for the hypothesis that recovery from stress is a potentially informative component of the contribution of stress responsivity to cardiovascular disease. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Jackson, Robert W.; Treiber, Frank A.; Turner, J. Rick; Davis, Harry; Strong, William B.

title: Attitude formation from product trial: Distinct roles of cognition and affect for hedonic and functional products.
abstract: Affective and cognitive responses to a product trial are examined in an experiment containing 2 cells representing 2 product types: hedonic and functional. The stimulus products were a computer game and grammar-checking software. Ss were 42 college students. The specific affective responses studied were pleasure and arousal, and brand cognitions are represented as the expectancy value from brand attributes. The relative level and influence of affective and cognitive responses to a product trial were shown to differ significantly, depending on whether the product was hedonic or functional in nature. Specifically, for the hedonic product, felt arousal during the trial was higher than for the functional product, and emotional responses were significant antecedents of Ss' evaluations of the trial experience. Brand cognitions, however, were not significantly related to trial evaluations for the hedonic product. In contrast, for the functional product, brand cognitions and pleasure were significant antecedents of trial evaluations, but arousal was not. Findings of this study demonstrate the importance of considering both the cognitive structure created by a product trial and the consumer's emotional reactions to the trial. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Kempf, DeAnna S.

title: Risk for hypertension and pain sensitivity in women.
abstract: To evaluate the possible negative association between risk for hypertension and pain sensitivity in women, 24 healthy young adult women with a parental history of hypertension and 24 without a parental history of hypertension participated in 2 laboratory sessions in which electric shock and the cold-pressor test were administered. To assess the possible role of stress-induced analgesia in blood pressure-related hypoalgesia, the sessions were identical with the exception of the fact that participants were exposed to a stressful 20-min video game before the pain stimuli on one occasion and a nonstressful control task on the other. Women with a parental history of hypertension and high blood pressure reactivity to the video game displayed a reduced sensitivity to electric shock on both days, suggesting that risk for hypertension is associated with reduced sensitivity to at least some pain stimuli in women. Blood pressure reactivity to stress-associated baroreceptor stimulation was not implicated as a mediator of decreased pain perception. However, other analyses revealed an effect of family history on shock pain only among women who reported relatively high anxiety, suggesting that other aspects of the stress response may be involved in this phenomenon. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Ditto, Blaine; France, Janis; France, Christopher R.

title: Is Mr Pac Man eating our children? A review of the effect of video games on children.
abstract: Reviewed the English-language literature in MEDLINE and PsycINFO from 1966 to 1996 regarding the effects of playing video games on the well-being of children. Results show that playing video games is associated with a variety of physical effects including increased metabolic and heart rate, seizures, and tendinitis. Aggressive behavior may result from playing video games, especially among younger children. There is no direct relationship between psychopathology or academic performance and playing video games. Overall findings indicate that although video games have some adverse effects, they are also valuable learning tools. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: The Canadian Journal of Psychiatry / La Revue canadienne de psychiatrie
authors: Emes, Craig E.

title: Predictors of differences between Type A and B individuals in heart rate and blood pressure reactivity.
abstract: Past estimates of the magnitude of Type A-B differences in cardiovascular reactivity are probably overly conservative. In addition, it is unclear which situations are more likely to elicit excessive reactivity in Type As. The present meta-analysis found that, overall, Type As had greater heart rate (mean d = .22), diastolic blood pressure (d = .22), and especially systolic blood pressure responses (d = .33) than Type Bs; these effect sizes were small but relatively consistent. However, Type As showed especially greater cardiovascular reactivity in situations characterized as having (1) positive or negative feedback evaluation, (2) socially aversive elements such as verbal harassment or criticism, and (3) elements inherent in playing video games. Measures of time urgency, Type A assessment method, and gender were not found to be strongly related to A-B differences in cardiovascular reactivity. Future studies that use more 'Type A-relevant' situations will probably find greater effects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Lyness, Scott A.

title: The effects of imagery-manipulated appraisal on intensity and direction of competitive anxiety.
abstract: Attempted to manipulate an athlete's facilitative or debilitative appraisal of competitive anxiety through imagery-based interventions in order to study the effects on subsequent anxiety intensity and direction. In a within-Ss design, 24 experienced soccer players were relaxed via progressive relaxation audiotape and then randomly underwent an imagery-based video and audiotaped manipulation of their appraisal of taking a hypothetical game winning penalty kick under either a 'pressure' or 'challenge' appraisal emphasis. There was no significant effect for heart rate. For both intensity and direction scores the challenge condition produced less cognitive anxiety, less somatic anxiety, and more self-confidence than the pressure situation. This finding suggests that a challenge appraisal manipulation taught by applied sport psychologists might benefit athletes' performance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Hale, Bruce D.; Whitehouse, Adam

title: Whether to measure change from baseline or absolute level in studies of children's cardiovascular reactivity: A two-year follow-up.
abstract: Blood pressure and heart rate were measured at rest and during a TV video game in 399 healthy 3rd grade children and at 2-yr follow-up. Ss were classified according to race (60 Black, 337 White), gender (201 girls), body mass index (light/heavy), and video game performance (low score/high score). Irrespective of classification variable, absolute reactivity values (e.g., a heart rate of 110 bpm) tended to be more stable than change reactivity values (e.g., a heart rate change of 10 bpm). The greater stability of absolute values was most pronounced with systolic blood pressure. Absolute values were at least as stable as resting values and frequently demonstrated greater stability. Mean and maximal reactivities were correlated comparably. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Murphy, Joseph K.; Alpert, Bruce S.; Walker, Sammie S.

title: Towards the design and implementation of computer-modeled opponents for use in entertainment and educational software: Some initial considerations.
abstract: Notes that new approaches to artificial intelligence, particularly those using autonomous software agents encapsulated in software robots (softbots), have the potential to make an enormous impact on game-based artificial intelligence systems. Softbot-based autonomous software agents provide a framework capable of supporting psychologically based models of human behavior in a game environment. Used in this manner, softbots provide a new set of tools to explore the synthesis of human-like reasoning in complex and dynamic environments. This article explores some initial attempts to develop an exploratory, game-based, experimental environment capable of hosting softbot-based, psychological models of human behavior. Preliminary work in the design and implementation of a simple, extensible, softbot-based, computer-modeled opponent is also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Cressy, Colin J.

title: Erratum to The effect of video game violence on physiological desensitization to real-life violence [J. Exp. Social Psychol. 43 (2007) 489-496].
abstract: Reports an error in The effect of video game violence on physiological desensitization to real-life violence by Nicholas L. Carnagey, Craig A. Anderson and Brad J. Bushman (Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 2007[May], Vol 43[3], 489-496). The publisher regrets that some of the authors' corrections were not incorporated. The legend to Fig. 2 should read: 'Heart rate at baseline, after playing a video game, and while watching filmed real-life violence for violent and nonviolent video game players. Mean heart rates for violent and nonviolent video game players during the viewing of filmed real-life violence were 70.7 and 68.5, respectively. All means are adjusted for gender. Capped vertical bars denote 1 SE.' Some of the means in Fig. 3 do not correspond to the means in the text, and the legend is missing some information. Fig. 3 should be replaced with the figure and legend given in the erratum. On page 494, in the first paragraph, two F-tests are misreported. The fourth to the last sentence should be replaced with: 'Furthermore, nonviolent game participants had a slight (nonsignificant) increase in GSR change while viewing the film, F(1,127)=.52, p>.05, d=.13, whereas violent game participants showed a decrease in GSR, F(1,113)=7.19, p<.05, d=.50.' (The following abstract of the original article appeared in record [rid]2007-05686-020[/rid].) Past research shows that violent video game exposure increases aggressive thoughts, angry feelings, physiological arousal, aggressive behaviors, and decreases helpful behaviors. However, no research has experimentally examined violent video game effects on physiological desensitization, defined as showing less physiological arousal to violence in the real world after exposure to video game violence in the virtual world. This experiment attempts to fill this gap. Participants reported their media habits and then played one of eight violent or nonviolent video games for 20min. Next, participants watched a 10-min videotape containing scenes of real-life violence while heart rate (HR) and galvanic skin response (GSR) were monitored. Participants who previously played a violent video game had lower HR and GSR while viewing filmed real violence, demonstrating a physiological desensitization to violence. Results are interpreted using an expanded version of the General Aggression Model. Links between desensitization, antisocial, and prosocial behavior are discussed. (The following abstract of this article originally appeared in record [rid]2007-05686-020[/rid].) Past research shows that violent video game exposure increases aggressive thoughts, angry feelings, physiological arousal, aggressive behaviors, and decreases helpful behaviors. However, no research has experimentally examined violent video game effects on physiological desensitization, defined as showing less physiological arousal to violence in the real world after exposure to video game violence in the virtual world. This experiment attempts to fill this gap. Participants reported their media habits and then played one of eight violent or nonviolent video games for 20min. Next, participants watched a 10-min videotape containing scenes of real-life violence while heart rate (HR) and galvanic skin response (GSR) were monitored. Participants who previously played a violent video game had lower HR and GSR while viewing filmed real violence, demonstrating a physiological desensitization to violence. Results are interpreted using an expanded version of the General Aggression Model. Links between desensitization, antisocial, and prosocial behavior are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Carnagey, Nicholas L.; Anderson, Craig A.; Bushman, Brad J.

title: Components of Type A behavior pattern as predictors of neuroendocrine and cardiovascular reactivity in challenging tasks.
abstract: Tested the association between (1) components of the Type A behavior pattern measured by structured interview (SI) and (2) sympatho-adrenal activation indexed by urinary catecholamines, pituitary-adrenal responsiveness measured by salivary cortisol, cardiovascular activation measured by heart rate and pulse transit time, and renal sodium excretion. 16 university students completed the Jenkins Activity Survey and a laboratory session that included the performance of a video game. The highest levels of significance for univariate F-tests were obtained from cardiovascular reactivity and recovery measures and for dopamine and adrenaline measures when groups were formed by a median criterion to global Type A assessed by the SI: Hostility plus Time Urgency. High and low Dysphoria groups were identified by a model incorporating catecholamines, cardiovascular, and cortisol recovery measures. Results suggest a psychoendocrine influence on the adrenal cortex. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Svebak, Sven; Knardahl, Stein; Nordby, Helge; Aakvaag, Asbjørn

title: Self-efficacy as a component of active coping: Effects on cardiovascular reactivity.
abstract: Tested whether increased self-efficacy in active coping would increase cardiovascular response when effort is left unconstrained. 40 female college students (aged 18–21 yrs) were randomly assigned to low or high self-efficacy conditions. They completed 50 questions which helped the experimenter to manipulate self-efficacy by giving them false feedback that conformed to the efficacy condition they were assigned to. Ss then engaged in a video game shape-matching task, while their BP and heart rate were monitored. Results reveal that Ss in the high self-efficacy condition group had greater increases in BP than the Ss in the low self-efficacy group. No differences were observed in heart rate. It is concluded that self-efficacy for a task may be an integral part of the active coping process, indirectly affecting the BP response. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Gerin, William; Litt, Mark D.; Deich, James; Pickering, Thomas G.

title: An automated data collector for the study of human–computer interaction.
abstract: For his research on computer games as vehicles of instruction, the author developed a workstation that Ss may use to self-collect and record data while interacting with software. The advantage of this type of data-gathering/observational device is that it preserves and support a S's sense of autonomy and control in the experimental environment. This article discusses the rationale and general requirements for such an apparatus, as well as some limitations of building and using this type of research tool. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Hedden, Chet

title: Program involvement: Are moderate levels best for ad memory and attitude toward the ad?
abstract: Examined the impact of context on advertising effectiveness. 86 university students viewed a televised soccer game where the timing of commercials varied according to 2 experimental conditions. Half of the Ss viewed the game without commercial interruptions (commercials were shown at half time and before the post-game show), and the other 43 Ss were assigned to an intrusive condition where the commercials interrupted the game. Results show an inverted-U relationship between involvement with the television program and ad memory and attitude toward the ad. An increase in involvement from low to moderate levels of program involvement resulted in higher advertising effectiveness. However, further increases in program involvement beyond moderate to high levels lead to decreases in ad memory and attitude toward the ad. Results are interpreted in terms of arousal theory, and implications for the slotting and design of commercials are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Tavassoli, Nader T.; Shultz, Clifford J.; Fitzsimons, Gavan J.

title: Alternating task modules in isochronal distributed training of complex tasks.
abstract: Examined the generalizability of the spacing effect to an alternating task module (ATM) protocol for 3 complex tasks, each requiring multiple hours of practice. 43 18–30 yr olds were exposed to either the ATM protocol, which alternated sessions on algebra word problems and video-game-like tasks of Space Fortress and Phoenix, or a massed protocol which blocked sessions on the task. Spacing practice in the ATM protocol gave the Ss an advantage in learning and retention on Space Fortress and algebra word problems, and caused no decrement in performance on Phoenix. Arousal, not confidence or motivation, was implicated in the ATM advantage. Practical and theoretical implications of the relative speed of the ATM protocol are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Goettl, Barry P.; Yadrick, Robert M.; Connolly-Gomez, Catherine; Regian, J. Wesley; Shebilske, Wayne L.

title: Gender of opponent and Type A competitiveness predict cardiovascular responses during competition.
abstract: Explored associations between components of Type A behavior and cardiovascular reactivity (CDR) during solitary and interpersonal competition. The influence of the opponent's gender was also examined. Type A behavior was assessed with the student version of the Jenkins Activity Survey in 135 male and 61 female undergraduates. Ss competed on a video game task against the machine or against men or women. CDR differed little between the genders and was generally higher during competition against a man than during competition against the machine, regardless of Type A component scores. CDR was greater in men who scored higher on the hard-driving/competitive component when the opponent was a woman. Findings are explained in terms of arousal associated with competitive engagement and attitudes about competition against men and women. Neither the speed/impatience scale nor the total Type A measure was consistently related to CDR. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Felsten, Gary; Leitten, Christopher L.

title: Cardiovascular reactivity in Black adolescents: Influences of gender and emotional social support.
abstract: Examined the effects of gender and emotional social support on cardiovascular reactivity in 46 Black adolescents (aged 13–16 yrs). Ss completed a familial social support scale and were assessed as to body mass and physical activity. Systolic (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) were measured at rest and during a competitive video game. Male Ss who reported receiving high levels of emotional support from family had significantly higher SBP and DBP reactivity than did female Ss who reported receiving high levels of emotional support. Male Ss who reported receiving high levels of emotional support showed higher SBP and DBP reactivity relative to male Ss who report having low levels of emotional support. Social and cultural factors may explain these differential findings across gender. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Wilson, Dawn K.; Kliewer, Wendy; Bayer, Laura A.

title: Parental history of hypertension, sodium loading, and cardiovascular response to stress.
abstract: Examined the effect of sodium loading on the peripheral vascular responses to stress of offspring of hypertensives (HTs). 18 normotensive (NT) offspring of HTs and 18 NT offspring of NTs were exposed to a 1-hr shock-avoidance video-game procedure after 14 days of sodium loading and again after 14 days of placebo tablets. Order of sessions was counterbalanced between Ss in a double-blind design. In offspring of HTs, sodium loading elevated total peripheral resistance and norepinephrine responses to stress relative to placebo conditions and compared with offspring of NTs. These increases were accompanied by decreases in stroke volume and cardiac output. Sodium loading had no effect on offspring of NTs. Results suggest that the elevated resistance in offspring of HTs may suggest the initiation of pathological processes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Miller, Sydney B.; Friese, Marianne; Sita, Aurelio

title: Don't wait for the monsters to get you: A video game task to manipulate appraisals in real time.
abstract: A video-game paradigm is introduced for the manipulation of appraisals in an ongoing active-coping task. Differences in current appraisal conceptions and their implications for experimental approaches to the manipulation of appraisals are discussed. Furthermore, the advantages of using concurrent physiological measures are outlined. The features of the game aMAZE and a shell program called PLAYGAME are described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Kappas, Arvid; Pecchinenda, Anna

title: Pressor reactivity, ethnicity, and 24-hour ambulatory monitoring in children from hypertensive families.
abstract: Assessed blood pressure (BP) responses of 64 Black and 56 White boys (aged 7–16 yrs) with family histories of essential hypertension. BP was assessed during 4 laboratory conditions: orthostatis, a video game, dynamic exercise, and a cold forehead condition. Ambulatory BP measures were obtained during the 24 hrs following each condition. Black Ss exhibited higher 24-hr ambulatory systolic and diastolic BP than did White Ss. Regardless of ethnicity, systolic BP responses during orthostatis, video game, and cold forehead conditions were significantly related to ambulatory systolic BP. Associations between diastolic BP responses and ambulatory measurements were somewhat dependent upon ethnicity and lab task. 13 Ss who were retested after 1 yr showed stable ambulatory BP measures over the 1-yr period. Results suggest that absolute systolic BP responses are generalizable across lab and field conditions, regardless of ethnicity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Treiber, Frank A.; Murphy, Joseph K.; Davis, Harry; Raunikar, R. Austin; Pflieger, Kurt; Strong, William B.

title: Gender effects in the stereotyping of those with different kinds of computing experience.
abstract: Studied stereotypes of male and female target figures who could write computer programs, use a word processor, or play computer games. 42 male and 108 female undergraduates were asked to rate the described target figure on the 16 personality attributes previously used by G. Siann et al (see record [rid]1989-11698-001[/rid]). There was no evidence of negative stereotyping; few differences were found between the male and female target figures, and the pattern of ratings was similar for the 3 computer uses. Results indicate that irrespective of the sex of the target figure, stereotyping of the 3 uses differed according to the sex of the respondent. Females gave higher ratings on attributes reflecting autonomy and congeniality to the figures who could write a computer program, while males gave these figures the lowest ratings on the same attributes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Colley, Ann; Hill, Fiona; Hill, Justin; Jones, Anna

title: Social support as a moderator of cardiovascular reactivity in women: A test of the direct effects and buffering hypotheses.
abstract: Determined whether social support operated as a moderator of cardiovascular reactivity in women. Two models of social support operation were examined: the direct-effects and buffering models. 26 women (aged 17–21 yrs) were exposed to 4 conditions while playing a video game: 2 levels of stress (low or high) and 2 levels of social support (alone or with a partner). BP and heart rate were monitored continuously. Ratings of stress were obtained for each condition. The support manipulation produced significant main effects for diastolic BP and stress ratings, with lower diastolic BP and ratings observed in the partnered condition. The interaction between support and stress produced lower reactivity for the cardiovascular measures in the high stress (but not the low stress) condition. Results support both the buffering and direct effects models. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Gerin, William; Milner, D'vorah; Chawla, Shalinee; Pickering, Thomas G.

title: Parental history of hypertension, menstrual cycle phase, and cardiovascular response to stress.
abstract: Examined whether inconsistent findings for elevated cardiovascular response to stress in female offspring of hypertensives might be a function of lack of control for menstrual cycle phase, and stressor type employed. 30 healthy women (aged 18–35 yrs), half of whom were offspring of hypertensives, were tested in both the luteal and follicular phases of the menstrual cycle. In each session, Ss were exposed to 4 tasks: the cold pressor test, interpersonal speech, shock-avoidance video-game, and reading. The most consistent menstrual cycle effect was for offspring of normotensives who exhibited higher diastolic blood pressure and state-anger responses to the speech task in the follicular compared with the luteal phase. Though menstrual cycle had no consistent effect on offspring of hypertensives, their luteal phase diastolic blood pressure and state-anger responses to the speech task were elevated compared with controls. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Miller, Sydney B.; Sita, Aurelio

title: Effects of odors on Fm theta rhythm.
abstract: Studied the effects of odors in indoor air on emotional states and efficiency of mental tasks using the psychophysiologic measure frontal midline theta rhythm, an EEG component usually elicited by mental arithmetic. 36 normal female Japanese adults (undergraduate students) (Exp 1). 29 normal female Japanese adults (undergraduate students) (Exp 2). In Exp 1 Ss participated in 2 trials of a high-involved mental task (video game) or a low-involved task (simple arithmetic). No odors were presented in Trial 1. Ss were presented with 1 of 3 natural scents (peppermint, lavender, or jasmine) in Trial 2. In Exp 2 ammonia as an example of a bad odor was presented to Ss in the same experimental design as in Exp 1. (English abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Ohira, Hideki; Unno, Ayako

title: Heart rate reactivity to laboratory tasks and in two daily life settings.
abstract: Investigated relationships between laboratory task-related heart rate (HR) reactivity and HR responses in 2 daily life settings to demonstrate that the expression of HR reactivity during daily life depends on the nature of the daily life situation (DLS), or on subjective or behavioral responses in the DLS. 26 healthy, male medical students completed 1 laboratory session (consisting of pretask rest, reaction time (RT), video game, and mental arithmetic conditions) and 2 day-long field study periods, during which Ss either worked as student physicians in a medical clinic or attended classroom lectures. HR levels were significantly higher during clinic work periods, compared to classroom work periods and evenings of both days. HR responses to laboratory tasks correlated significantly with minimum, mean, and maximum HR responses from the clinic work period. Results replicate the findings of M. H. Pollak (see record [rid]1991-17708-001[/rid]). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Pollak, Michael H.

title: The mental simulation of better and worse possible worlds.
abstract: Investigated the spontaneous generation of upward counterfactuals (CTFs) which improve reality, and downward CTFs which worsen reality, with 88 undergraduates playing a computer-simulated blackjack game. The outcome was framed to be perceived as either a win, a neutral, or a loss event. Loss frames produced more upward and fewer downward CTFs than win or neutral frames, but the overall prevalence of CTF thinking did not vary with outcome valence. Ss who expected to play the game again made more upward CTFs and were less satisfied with the outcome than Ss who did not expect to play again. However, once Ss saw the cards from which they could have selected had they 'hit' again (2 winning cards and 2 losing cards), all Ss generated primarily upward CTFs and showed a corresponding decrease in satisfaction. These results implicate cognitive and motivational factors in the generation of CTF thinking. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Markman, Keith D.; Gavanski, Igor; Sherman, Steven J.; McMullen, Matthew N.

title: The effect of laboratory stressors on glycemic control and gastrointestinal transit time.
abstract: Compared effects of an active coping task (computerized stressors involving arithmetic, anagrams, and Atari games) and a passive coping task (cold pressor) on gastrointestinal transit time and glycemic response to an oral glucose load. 11 male undergraduates participated in 3 counterbalanced sessions, each including a 45-min baseline, 20-min experimental period, and 2.5-hr recovery period. The stressors produced different cardiovascular and catecholamine responses; systolic and diastolic blood pressure were highest during cold pressor, heart rate was highest during computer stressor, and norepinephrine excretion was greatest during cold pressor. However, both stressors delayed gastrointestinal transit time and both delayed the time of peak glucose response. Implications of these findings for patients with diabetes and for effects of stress on eating behavior are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Blair, Elaine H.; Wing, Rena R.; Wald, Arnold

title: Aerobic fitness, psychological characteristics, and cardiovascular reactivity to stress.
abstract: Examined relations among aerobic fitness (AF), psychological characteristics, and cardiovascular reactivity, using 62 men (mean age 42 yrs) divided into highly fit and less fit groups based on a treadmill exercise test. Several psychological and physiological variables were measured, and Ss' cardiovascular reactivity was assessed during a mental arithmetic task and a video game task. Highly fit Ss showed a significantly smaller increase in diastolic blood pressure (DBP) and heart rate (HR) and reported themselves to be less anxious and less angry than did less fit Ss. Controlling for Ss' scores on a scale assessing angry temperament reduced the relationship between AF and DBP reactivity to nonsignificant levels. Degree of dispositional anger, which covaries with increased fitness, may contribute to the relationship between AF and DBP, but not HR, reactivity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Czajkowski, Susan M.; Hindelang, R. David; Dembroski, Theodore M.; Mayerson, Suzin E.; Parks, Edward B.; Holland, John C.

title: Expressive, but not neurotic hostility is related to cardiovascular reactivity during a hostile competitive task.
abstract: Examined relationships between the expressive and neurotic hostility components of the Buss-Durkee Hostility-Guilt Inventory and cardiovascular (CV) reactivity in 25 men and 18 women undergraduates. Ss competed against and were harassed by a male confederate during competition on a video game. Ss with expressive hostility scores above the median had higher systolic BP and heart rate reactivity than Ss with scores below the median. Neurotic hostility was not related to CV reactivity. Results support the hypothesis that CV reactivity may be a risk factor in the development of coronary heart disease and suggest that attempts to relate dimensions of hostility to CV reactivity may be more successful if dimensions of hostility unrelated to neuroticism are studied. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Felsten, Gary; Leitten, Christopher L.

title: Predicting ambulatory blood pressure during school: Effectiveness of social and nonsocial reactivity tasks in Black and White adolescents.
abstract: Evaluated a newly developed stress task, a social competence interview, and 3 nonsocial tasks (video game, mirror drawing, and mental arithmetic) for ability to predict ambulatory blood pressure (BP) in 237 Black and White adolescents (aged 13–16 yrs). Only the BP response to an interview enhanced prediction of classroom and transition systolic and diastolic pressures in the total sample. Mirror drawing improved prediction of transition systolic BP in the total sample. Racial subgroup analyses revealed that interview data predicted systolic pressure in Whites but predicted diastolic pressure in Blacks, indicating biological differences in BP regulation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Ewart, Craig K.; Kolodner, Kenneth B.

title: Affective moderators of the cardiovascular response to stress in offspring of hypertensives.
abstract: Examined the influence of trait anxiety on the cardiovascular responses of normotensive offspring of hypertensives and normotensives. 48 men, half of whom were offspring of hypertensives (PH+), were exposed to an extended active coping stressor. This was a 1-hr shock avoidance procedure with avoidance contingent on video-game performance. PH+ Ss who scored high on trait anxiety exhibited greater elevations of heart rate and forearm blood flow, and decreases in forearm vascular resistance than did PH+/low trait anxiety Ss or offspring of normotensives (PH–). Cardiovascular responses of PH+/low trait anxiety Ss did not differ from those of PH– Ss. Results suggest affective factors may moderate cardiovascular responses of indviduals at risk for hypertension. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Miller, S. B.

title: Social Competence Interview for assessing physiological reactivity in adolescents.
abstract: Compared the Social Competence Interview (SCI), which measures physiological changes elicited by re-experiencing a life situation, to video game, mirror drawing (MD), and mental arithmetic (MA) in 260 Ss (aged 14–15 yrs). Blood pressure (BP) changes during SCI exceeded those during the other tasks, and were unaffected by race or gender. Test–retest correlations over 6 mo in a random subsample of 27 Ss showed that BP reactivity to SCI and other tasks was reproducible. The SCI was rated by Ss as less frustrating or demanding than MD or MA. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Ewart, Craig K.; Kolodner, Kenneth B.

title: The use and experience of the new video media among children and young adolescents.
abstract: Examined the use and experience of new video media (music videos, videocassettes, video games) and TV viewing, music listening, and reading in 483 students (aged 9–15 yrs). Ss carried electronic paging devices and reported their activities and subjective experiences when signaled. For boys, new video media were associated with higher reports of arousal and more positive affective states than for TV viewing, reading, and listening to popular music. Girls reported lower affect and arousal, especially during video games and music videos. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Kubey, Robert; Larson, Reed

title: Zur Vorhersage zielgerichteten Handelns: Einstellung, Subjektive Handlungskompetenz und Emotionen. = The prediction of goal-directed behavior: Attitude, subjective estimations of competence, and emotions.
abstract: Tested an extension of I. Ajzen's (1985) theory of planned behavior that includes an emotional component. Human Ss: 64 normal male and female West German adults (university students). Ss played 2 video games (a speed-oriented and a problem-oriented game) in an achievement-motivation situation. Half of the Ss played easy versions of both games; and the other half played difficult versions. Ss' attitudes toward playing the games, their emotional reactions while playing the games, and their feelings of competence were analyzed in relation to the difficulty levels of the games. In addition, the predictive validity of activity- and security-oriented emotions in the theory of planned behavior was analyzed. (English abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Zeitschrift für Experimentelle und Angewandte Psychologie
authors: Doll, Jörg; Mentz, Michael; Orth, Bernhard

title: Calculation of additional heart rates using oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production: A comparative analysis.
abstract: Examined whether oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production were themselves intimately related, so as to make carbon-dioxide-production measures appropriate in the additional-heart-rate methodology. Data from the study by J. R. Turner et al (see record [rid]1989-21622-001[/rid]) were reexamined. Additional heart rates during mental arithmetic and a video game were separately calculated for 24 healthy young men by first using oxygen consumption and then by using carbon dioxide production. The values obtained were highly correlated, and the coefficients for the task periods themselves were 0.99 and 0.96, respectively. Use of carbon-dioxide-production data in this manner would, therefore, seem to be appropriate. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Thayer, Julian F.; Van Doornen, L. J.; Turner, J. Rick

title: Heart rate reactivity to laboratory tasks and ambulatory heart rate in daily life.
abstract: Investigated relationships between laboratory task-related heart-rate (HR) reactivity and ambulatory HR responses and variability during daily life. 62 healthy men (aged 18–35 yrs) completed 1 lab session consisting of pretask rest, reaction time (RT), video game, and mental arithmetic, and 1 24-hr ambulatory HR monitoring day. Results support the hypothesis that individual differences in HR responses to lab tasks reflect similar differences in HR responses and variability during daily life. Results are compared in their degree of support for 2 theoretical models by S. B. Manuck and D. S. Krantz (1984) describing the generalization of individual differences in lab reactivity to reactivity during daily life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Pollak, Michael H.

title: Effects of feedback and contingent reinforcement in reducing heart rate response to stress.
abstract: Developed a training protocol to investigate the effect of contingent reinforcement in reducing heart rate (HR) response to stress in 48 healthy male adults. Ss were given both HR feedback (FB) and a behavioral stressor, a computerized videogame. The videogame was used during assessment and training, and a mental arithmetic challenge was given only during the pre- and posttraining assessment. Ss were divided into training groups that (1) received FB/no-FB while playing the videogame and (2) played the videogame either with a combined reinforcement score contingency or with reinforcement based solely on game performance. Results confirm that regulation of HR response during behavioral challenges could be readily learned. There was an absence of any observable HR change for any experimental group across training trials. Ss trained using the combined score contingency showed greater reductions in HR response to the mental arithmetic challenge. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Larkin, Kevin T.; Zayfert, Claudia; Veltum, Lois G.; Abel, Jennifer L.

title: 'A multi-component social skills intervention for children with Asperger syndrome: The Junior Detective Training Program': Errata.
abstract: Reports an error in 'A multi-component social skills intervention for children with Asperger syndrome: The Junior Detective Training Program' by Renae Beaumont and Kate Sofronoff (Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, 2008[Jul], Vol 49[7], 743-753). The following errors occurred in the article: On Page 743, line 9: (ASDs) has been published incorrectly as (Asbs). On Page 744, line 32: 'hypotheses' has been published incorrectly has 'hypothesis'. In line 52: 'skill generalization' has been published incorrectly as 'skills generalization'. On Page 752, line 44: Appendix A: Session 6, Teacher handout recommendations: 'pro-social' has been published incorrectly as 'pre-social'. (The following abstract of the original article appeared in record [rid]2008-08376-008[/rid]). Background: The study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a new multi-component social skills intervention for children with Asperger syndrome (AS): The Junior Detective Training Program. This 7-week program included a computer game, small group sessions, parent training sessions and teacher handouts. Method: Forty-nine children with AS were recruited to participate and randomly assigned to intervention (n = 26) or wait-list control (n = 23) conditions. Results: Relative to children in the waitlist group, program participants showed greater improvements in social skills over the course of the intervention, as indicated by parent-report measures. Teacher-report data also confirmed that children receiving the intervention made significant improvements in social functioning from pre- to posttreatment. Treatment group participants were better able to suggest appropriate emotion-management strategies for story characters at post-intervention than at pre-intervention, whereas control participants were not. However, there was no difference in the improvements made by children in the intervention and control conditions on facial expression and body-posture recognition measures. Follow-up data suggested that treatment gains were maintained by children at 5-months post-intervention. Conclusions: The Junior Detective Training Program appeared to be effective in enhancing the social skills and emotional understanding of children with AS. Limitations and suggestions for future research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry
authors: Beaumont, Renae; Sofronoff, Kate

title: Reducing heart rate reactivity to stress with feedback: Generalization across task and time.
abstract: Heart rate (HR) reactions to 2 behavioral stressors (videogame [VG] and mental arithmetic [MAR]) were measured in 8 experimental (EXP) Ss who received biofeedback training and 8 matched control Ss (all Ss aged 18–24 yrs) during 3 assessment periods: pretraining, posttraining, and 1-wk follow-up. EXP Ss exhibited significant reductions in HR following a training session in which they received ongoing HR feedback while playing a VG. Controls, who played the same number of VGs without HR feedback, showed smaller HR reductions. Compared with controls, EXP Ss maintained lower HRs during VG presentations after a 1-wk period and generalized these HR reductions to the MAR challenge at follow-up. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Larkin, Kevin T.; Zayfert, Claudia; Abel, Jennifer L.; Veltum, Lois G.

title: Type A behavior as a generally available strategy: Varying activation by tasks and instructions.
abstract: 69 university students classified as Type A or not-A by structured interview performed physical exercise, a vigilance task, and a videogame with or without challenging instructions. For the (effort-salient) exercise, instructions produced a mean increase in arousal regardless of behavior pattern, while in the vigilance (low salience) task they produced no effect. Only in the videogame task did behavior pattern classification predict arousal in interaction with instructions. Effort, measured by performance, showed a trend to increase with challenging instructions. Ratings by Ss of physical feelings paralleled these results, but positive, negative, and emotional feelings did not show behavior pattern or instruction effects. Results support Type A as a generally available response to which individuals show a differential activation rather than a character trait. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Jones, K. V.

title: Cardiac and metabolic activity in mild hypertensive and normotensive subjects.
abstract: Monitored heart rate (HR), respiration, and metabolic activity at rest and during a video game in 22 mild hypertensive (MHT) and 53 normotensive (NT) men. The MHT Ss had higher resting HRs than the NT Ss and larger magnitude HR increases to the video game. Correlational analyses within each group revealed that whereas systolic blood pressure was positively and significantly related to neuroticism (Eysenck Personality Questionnaire) in the MHT Ss, for the NT Ss the direction of correlation was reversed. Scores on the Jenkins Activity Survey correlated positively with HR reactivity to the video game for the MHT Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Sims, Jane; Carroll, Douglas; Turner, J. Rick; Hewitt, John K.

title: Cardiac and metabolic responses to 'space invaders': An instance of metabolically-exaggerated cardiac adjustment?
abstract: Monitored heart rate plus various ventilatory and metabolic indices while 24 18–28 yr old males played a computer game (Space Invaders) and during a control condition in which analogous but ineffective actions were requested and the game proceeded automatically. Relative to baseline, Ss showed much larger increases in heart rate during the game than during the control condition. O₂ consumption, CO₂ production, and respiratory rate and volume also increased more. While the absolute magnitude of metabolic differences between conditions was modest relative to heart rate differences, the existence of highly significant differences in O₂ consumption and CO₂ production militated against assertions of overall cardiac-metabolic independence during the game; however, analysis of individual differences in heart rate reactivity provided some evidence of metabolically unjustified heart rate changes while playing the game. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Turner, J. Rick; Carroll, Douglas; Courtney, Hazel

title: Cardiovascular responses to an extended aversive video game task.
abstract: 24 healthy male undergraduates participated in both 1-hr shock avoidance and separate counterbalanced baseline sessions. The S could avoid mild electric shocks depending on video game performance. The primary dependent measures were heart rate (HR), digital blood volume pulse (DBVP), and blood pressure (BP). Most Ss exhibited immediate pronounced increases in HR in response to the stressor, followed by some habituation. DBVP responses did not usually habituate. BP was more or less constantly elevated by the stressor. Individual differences in mean arterial BP response to the stressor were significantly related to individual differences in HR response to the 1st 15 min but increasingly unrelated to HR response and more related to DBVP response as the session progressed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Miller, Sydney B.; Ditto, Blaine

title: Temporal consistency of individual differences in cardiac response to a video game.
abstract: Conducted 3 experiments that examined the temporal stability of cardiac reactions to a videogame of the 'space invaders' genre. In Exp I, intertask consistency was also addressed. Along with the videogame, 42 male Ss (mostly undergraduates) were presented with an unsignalled RT task and led to believe that relatively quick reactions attracted financial reward, while slower ones brought either a burst of loud noise or withdrawal of money previously earned. Findings indicate that, of the 2 tasks, the videogame elicited the greater reactivity, and individual variations in reactivity showed striking temporal stability for both tasks. In Exp II, 3 extreme-high and 3 extreme-low cardiac reactors were selected from an initial sample of 23 male undergraduates on the basis of reactivity during an initial session with the videogame and subsequently studied during 4 further sessions. Once more, impressive stability of heart-rate reactivity was apparent over sessions. In Exp III, whether temporal stability is constrained by menstrual-cycle effects was investigated. 12 females aged 17 yrs and 12 females aged 24–38 yrs were tested on the videogame both preovulatory and postovulatory, with half being tested first during the preovulatory phase and half being tested first during the postovulatory phase. Results again reveal a marked stability of individual variations in cardiac reactivity over both time and menstrual cycle phase. (24 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Carroll, Douglas; Turner, J. R.; Lee, H. J.; Stephenson, J.

title: Respiratory sinus arrhythmia as an index of parasympathetic cardiac control during active coping.
abstract: 20 healthy undergraduates played a video game with and without threat of shock for inferior performance. Results suggest that cardiac parasympathetic activity was diminished from rest to task, contributing to heart rate (HR) responses. Exaggerated HR responses were also associated with extreme parasympathetic withdrawal. Interaction effects showed that threat of shock during the 1st task condition was effective in elevating HR and reducing respiratory stress arrhythmia. A repeated-measures analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) of HR suggested that sympathetic influences on HR exceeded reciprocal vagal effects during the threat condition for Ss exposed to the threat task first. Findings indicate the importance of considering stress-related parasympathetic effects on HR as well as sympathetic-vagal interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Grossman, Paul; Svebak, Sven

title: Constructions of emotion: Discrepancy, arousal, and mood.
abstract: Used an interactive adventure-type computer game to explore the constructive components of emotional experience, sympathetic nervous system arousal, and evaluative cognitions postulated by discrepancy/evaluation theory (G. Mandler; 1975, 1984, 1990). Ss were 12 undergraduates whose heart rate, galvanic skin response, and respiration were recorded continuously during each game in 20-sec sets. Subjective ratings of mood intensity were also collected. Manipulations of expectations produced significant and large heart rate changes for both positive and negative discrepancies. Autonomic response also reflected the degree of interruption/discrepancy produced by an event. Negatively toned (discrepant) events produced significant intensity and higher overall autonomic arousal. In addition, Ss' intensity of experience was related to their autonomic response.
