(PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: MacDowell, Kathleen A.; Mandler, George

title: Reliability and validity of portable blood pressure/pulse units during a competitive challenge.
abstract: Examined the reliability and validity of recordings from 3 portable blood pressure/pulse units compared with simultaneous recordings from a polygraph used as the standard for these comparisons. 30 healthy Ss (aged 14–65 yrs) were exposed to Pac-Man video game and mental arithmetic stressors. The blood pressure/pulse readings from the digital units by Sears and Industrial Biomedical Sensor corresponded more closely to simultaneous polygraph recordings than did the analog scale device by Sphygmostat. Results suggest that the digital blood pressure/pulse units employed in this investigation are reliable and valid measurement devices suitable for field research with clinical populations. (12 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Follick, Michael J.; Ahern, David K.; Gorkin, Larry

title: A twin study of cardiac reactivity and its relationship to parental blood pressure.
abstract: The cardiac reactivity of 40 monozygotic and 40 dizygotic pairs of young male twins, aged 16–24 yrs, was monitored during psychological challenge, as afforded by a video game. A simple genetic model that implicated additive genetic effects, along with those stemming from individual environments, best fitted the data. Data suggest individual differences in cardiac reactivity have a heritable component and that high reactivity may be a precursor of elevated blood pressure. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Carroll, Douglas; Hewitt, John K.; Last, Krystyna A.; Turner, J. Rick; Sims, Jane

title: Behavioral response demands, cardiovascular reactivity, and essential hypertension.
abstract: Examined psychophysiologic reactions to behavioral challenges in 36 men aged 55 or younger with no prior history of cardiovascular disorder. Three age-matched groups were recruited through factory screening: mild hypertensives, transient hypertensives, and normotensives. Clinical examination, a laboratory rest session, and period of blood pressure self-monitoring were followed by a laboratory stress session. The latter involved performance of 2 tasks demanding active behavioral coping (an interference task and video game) and 1 passive condition (a distressing movie). Mild hypertensives showed significantly greater pressor reactions (both in absolute and percentage terms) than normotensives to tasks requiring active behavioral coping, but not to the passive condition. The transient hypertension group produced heightened reactions in diastolic but not systolic pressure. Greater heart rate and pulse transit time reactions were also observed in the transient group, suggesting that exaggerated cardiac responsiveness to active challenges may be characteristic of the prehypertensive profile. (53 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Steptoe, Andrew; Melville, Donald; Ross, Alvin

title: Cardiovascular reactivity to psychological stress in healthy children.
abstract: Presents normative percentile data on the hemodynamic responses (heart rate and blood pressure) of 310 healthy Black and White children (aged 6–18 yrs) to the stress of a TV video game. A series of 3 video games played under 3 increasing levels of stress elicited progressively higher values of blood pressure and heart rate. Both Ss' race and gender, as well as the experimenter's race, significantly affected reactivity. Ss demonstrated a range of interchild reactivity, allowing separation of individuals into high- and low-risk percentile groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Murphy, Joseph K.; Alpert, Bruce S.; Willey, Elaine S.; Somes, Grant W.

title: 'Social cognitions as organizers of autonomic and affective responses to social challenge': Correction to Bugental et al.
abstract: Reports an error in the original article by D. B. Bugental et al (Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 1993, Vol 64[1], 94–203). On page 97, the sentence 'SCL was measured by bipolar silver-silver chloride electrodes placed on the thumb of the nonpreferred hand' should read as follows: 'SCL was measured by bipolar silver-silver chloride electrodes placed on the thenar and hypothenar eminences of the nonpreferred hand.' (The following abstract of this article originally appeared in record [rid]1993-21385-001[/rid].) Autonomic and affective responses to children were assessed as a function of adult perceptions of interpersonal control. Women (N = 160) interacted with and provided feedback to computer-simulated children who behaved responsively or unresponsively on a computer game. Women were categorized as low in perceived control (PC) if they attributed high control to children but low control to self over negative events on the Parent Attribution Test. As predicted, low-PC women were maximally reactive to child characteristics, manifesting peak levels of defensive arousal (increased level of heart rate and electrodermal activity) and negative affect with unresponsive children and minimal levels of arousal and negative affect with responsive children … (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
authors: Daphne Blunt, Bugental; Jay, Blue; Victoria, Cortez; Karen, Fleck; Hal, Kopeikin; Jeffrey Clayton, Lewis; Judith, Lyon

title: Plasma norepinephrine pharmacokinetics during mental challenge.
abstract: 14 healthy Ss (mean age 27 yrs) were simultaneously infused iv with tracer-labeled norepinephrine (NE) and isoproterenol to measure forearm and total body NE pharmacokinetics at rest and in response to mental challenge (video game or cognitive task). Mental challenge was associated with increased heart rate, systolic blood pressure, cardiac output, forearm blood flow, and the rate of release of endogenous NE into arterial blood. Results indicate that mental challenge is associated with generally increased sympathetically-mediated NE release that determines the hemodynamic responses. Because of regional changes in sympathetic activity and blood flow during psychological stress, changes in antecubital venous NE and even arterial NE may not reflect accurately sympathetic nerve activity. However, measurement of total body and regional NE pharmacokinetics avoids these difficulties. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Goldstein, David S.; Eisenhofer, Graeme; Sax, Frederic L.; Keiser, Harry R.; Kopin, Irwin J.

title: Commentary: C. Ward.
abstract: Comments on an article by P.J. Standen and D.J. Brown (see record [rid]2005-06838-025[/rid]). The authors have summarized major advantages of VR systems for people with impairments in cognition and in social functioning. I would like to draw attention to one additional positive feature of VR, namely its close relationship to everyday technologies. Thus, VR users can perceive themselves to be on a continuum with society at large, where computer usage is a potent symbol of social participation. The authors make a very convincing case for the use of virtual environments in the assessment and facilitation of autonomous action. It is hard to think of any paradigm that could rival VR as a means of assessing and encouraging decision-making. The commercial development of environments and 'intelligent agents' for computer games, in-car computers, and so on means that the costs of hardware will fall, and the sophistication of software will rise. In the future, we can surely expect progressively more visual realism, with, let us hope, cheaper ways of constructing virtual copies of real environments. The extension of VR to social interaction seems to have great potential, and this will continue to increase in line with technical developments. In the meantime, it is reassuring to read that there might be benefits for all of us in playing computer games. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Ward, Christopher D.

title: A comparison of additional heart rates during active psychological challenge calculated from upper body and lower body dynamic exercise.
abstract: Recorded heart rate (HR), oxygen consumption (OC), and blood pressure while 22 males performed a stressful mental arithmetic task and played a video game. Measurements were also made while Ss undertook 2 separate graded dynamic exercise tasks. All measures changed as a function of psychological challenge; and during exercise, HR and OC changed as a function of workload. For each S, HR was plotted against OC over the various workloads for each exercise task separately. Actual HR during psychological challenge was greater than predicted HR (there was considerable additional HR), irrespective of whether upper or lower body exercise was involved. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Turner, J. Rick; Carroll, Douglas; Hanson, Jane; Sims, Jane

title: Arterial pulse transit time and ECG-initiated transit time: The form of the conditioned responses.
abstract: Arterial pulse transit time (PTT), EKG-initiated transit time (EKG-TT), and interbeat interval were recorded during a differential classical conditioning procedure with a commercial video game functioning as the UCS in 2 experiments with 18 university students. In Exp I, 10 Ss were presented with 20 acquisition trials. Both PTT and EKG-TT showed differential changes to the CS+ and CS–. The PTT CR took the form of a decrease in transit time, reaching maximum between 5 and 7 beats after CS onset, and the EKG-TT response was biphasic, consisting of an initial lengthening from baseline during the 1st 3 beats after CS onset followed by a decrease below baseline, reaching maximum at Beats 8–20. Exp II was a replication of Exp I: Eight Ss received 40 acquisition trials. PTT and EKG-TT CRs were similar to those observed in Exp I and persisted during the 40 trials. The PTT decrease from baseline during Beats 5–7 was significant, as were the deceleratory and acceleratory EKG-TT components. The cardiovascular CRs occurring prior to the video game appeared to be similar to the preparatory cardiovascular responses observed during the foreperiod of an RT task. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Redman, Selina; Dutch, John

title: Erratum to: 'The production and recognition of emotions in speech: Features and algorithms' [Int. J. Hum.-Comput. Stud. 59 (2003) 157].
abstract: Reports an error in the original article by Pierre-Yves Oudeyer (International Journal of Human-Computer Studies, 2003[Jul], Vol 59[1-2], 157-183). The name of the author has not been given correctly in the published paper. The author's correct name is Pierre-Yves Oudeyer. (The following abstract of this article originally appeared in record [rid]2003-06408-009[/rid].) This paper presents algorithms that allow a robot to express its emotions by modulating the intonation of its voice. They are very simple and efficiently provide life-like speech thanks to the use of concatenative speech synthesis. We describe a technique which allows to continuously control both the age of a synthetic voice and the quantity of emotions that are expressed. Also, we present the first large-scale data mining experiment about the automatic recognition of basic emotions in informal everyday short utterances. We focus on the speaker-dependent problem. We compare a large set of machine learning algorithms, ranging from neural networks, Support Vector Machines or decision trees, together with 200 features, using a large database of several thousands examples. We show that the difference of performance among learning schemes can be substantial, and that some features which were previously unexplored are of crucial importance. An optimal feature set is derived through the use of a genetic algorithm. We explain how this study can be applied to real world situations in which very few examples are available. Furthermore, we describe a game to play with a personal robot which facilitates teaching of examples of emotional utterances in a natural and unconstrained manner. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Oudeyer, Pierre-Yves

title: Individual differences in heart rate response during behavioral challenge.
abstract: Discusses a program of experiments (e.g., J. R. Turner and D. Carroll; see record [rid]1986-13875-001[/rid]) that examined heart rate (HR) responses to mental arithmetic and a video game. The metabolic relevance of HR responses was emphasized. Comparison with HR/oxygen consumption regression equations generated from isotonic exercise data revealed HR increases in certain individuals in excess of those necessitated by contemporary metabolic demand. Evidence was obtained to support both temporal and intertask consistency of reaction. The relationship between laboratory and real-world reactions was investigated, and preliminary evidence suggests that laboratory HR responses are indicative of responses to more naturalistic stressors. Twin studies that examined genetic and environmental determinants of individual differences in HR change during the tasks revealed a substantial genetic component for these responses. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Turner, J. Rick

title: Temporal and inter-task consistency of heart rate reactivity during active psychological challenge: A twin study.
abstract: Heart rate (HR) was monitored while 22 pairs of male monozygotic and 29 pairs of male dizygotic twins (aged 16–26 yrs) were exposed to a video game and a mental arithmetic task. HR reactions of monozygotic Ss showed much greater concordance than those of dizygotic Ss. Data for the 102 Ss demonstrated reliable intertask consistency of HR. Comparison of HR reactions of 10 of the pairs of monozygotic and 10 of the pairs of dizygotic Ss who had been tested more than a year earlier and their present reactivities revealed temporal consistency. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Turner, J. Rick; Carroll, Douglas; Sims, Jane; Hewitt, John K.; Kelly, Krystyna A.

title: Selective cardiovascular effects of stress and cigarette smoking.
abstract: Examined whether both stress and smoking produce larger cardiovascular consequences than either factor alone. Stress was defined as playing a series of difficult video games under challenging instructional conditions. Following an initial test game, 51 male college student smokers were randomly assigned to a 2 (smoke vs sham smoke) × 2 (stress vs no stress) design. Ss assigned to the sham smoke condition (inhaling unlit cigarettes) under no stress evidenced minimal changes in cardiovascular parameters. Ss who smoked under no stress evidenced approximately 12 mmHg increases in systolic blood pressure, 9 mmHg increases in diastolic blood pressure, and a 15 beat/min increase in heart rate. These effects were similar in magnitude to those seen in Ss assigned to the sham smoke condition under stress. By contrast, Ss who smoked under stress showed markedly larger increases in all cardiovascular parameters, approximately doubling the magnitude of the observed response over that seen with either smoking or stress alone. Correlational analyses suggest the presence of stable individual differences in autonomic lability or sensitivity. Results also suggest that smoking mildly impaired psychomotor performance. Possible mechanisms are suggested whereby stress and smoking may combine to heighten the risk for coronary disease. (34 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: MacDougall, James M.; Dembroski, Theodore M.; Slaats, Stans; Herd, J. Alan; Eliot, Robert S.

title: Information load stress, risk taking, and physiological responsivity in a visual-motor task.
abstract: Investigated the effects of 4 levels of information load on performance, risk taking, and physiological responsivity (blood pressure and heart rate). 25 23–71 yr old males participated in a hand-eye coordination task presented as a video game. Increases in load resulted in performance decrements and increased proclivity to take risks. Participation in the task increased diastolic arousal. Load effects on arousal were negligible. Ss with greater diastolic blood pressure elevations engaged in more risk taking. The potential of 2 separate groupings of stressor effects, directly producing cognitive performance changes in one case and producing affective/arousal impacts in the other (with potential indirect effects on cognition and performance), is considered. (36 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Streufert, Siegfried; Streufert, Susan C.; Denson, Ann L.

title: Sympathetic indices during psychological and physical stimuli before and after training.
abstract: Studied the effects of psychological stimuli (playing a video game) and physical stimuli (sitting and standing) on cardiovascular and catecholamine changes before and after physical training in 8 labile hypertensive men (mean age 30 yrs). Ss underwent a 20-wk training program consisting of 3 45-min jogging sessions per week. The results show that plasma norepinephrine concentration rose with sitting and standing but plasma epinephrine concentration increased only with the psychological stimulus. Physical training was associated with smaller increases in blood pressure during psychological and physical stimuli and with a lower heart rate at rest. Plasma catecholamines at rest as well as in response to the different stimuli were unchanged following moderate training. These observations suggest that the adrenal medulla is selectively activated during a period of mild psychological stress, while the activity of the sympathetic fibers is preferentially increased during mild physical stimuli. Furthermore, the results show that plasma catecholamine levels at rest and their increase during various stimuli are unchanged following training. (34 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Cleroux, Jean; Peronnet, Francois; de Champlain, Jacques

title: The effects of aerobic fitness on additional heart rates during active psychological challenge.
abstract: Recorded heart rate (HR), oxygen consumption (VO₂), and blood pressure while 24 18–35 yr old males performed 2 active psychological tasks (mental arithmetic and a video game). Using data obtained during graded dynamic exercise, Ss were also divided into high fit (HF) and low fit (LF) groups. Findings indicate that both psychological tasks increased HR more than was predicted based on HR-VO₂ regressions derived from graded exercise. HR increases during psychological challenge were significantly greater in LF Ss than in HF Ss. Results suggest that greater aerobic fitness may be associated with attenuation of excessive cardiac responses to behavioral stressors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Turner, J. Rick; Carroll, Douglas; Costello, Marian; Sims, Jane

title: Play as a consumption experience: The roles of emotions, performance, and personality in the enjoyment of games.
abstract: Investigated the relationships among a personality variable (verbalizing/visualizing), type of game (verbal/visual), performance (success/failure), perceptions (complexity), and emotions (pleasure, arousal, and dominance) in a playful consumption experience. 60 graduates students (mean age 25.6 yrs) were given either a verbal or a visual version of a video game that was to be played on a home computer. Ss were asked to complete measures of performance, tendencies toward visualization/verbalization, emotions, and perceived complexity. Results suggest that performance, perceived complexity, and personality–game congruity determine emotional responses and that performance itself depends both on previous performance and on various ability-related individual characteristics. Although still tentative, such findings indicate an important role for the competence motive in the enjoyment of games. (61 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Holbrook, Morris B.; Chestnut, Robert W.; Oliva, Terence A.; Greenleaf, Eric A.

title: Cardiovascular and neurohumoral responses to behavioral challenge as a function of race and sex.
abstract: Cardiovascular and hormonal responses to a structured interview, an electronic video game, a cold pressor test, and exercise on a bicycle ergometer were assessed in 83 normotensive Black and White men and women (aged 25–44 yrs). Black Ss showed significantly greater diastolic blood pressure (DBP) responses than White Ss during the cold pressor test, which were not accounted for by an increase in plasma catecholamines. Exercise produced reliably greater systolic blood pressure (SBP) increases in Black women than in Black men or White women. Men showed significantly greater SBP and DBP changes than women during the video game. The pattern of physiological reactivity elicited by challenge may be related to the Ss' race and sex. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Tischenkel, Nancy J.; Saab, Patrice G.; Schneiderman, Neil; Nelesen, Richard A.; Pasin, Rosemary DeCarlo; Goldstein, David A.; Spitzer, Susan B.; Woo-Ming, Rex; Weidler, Donald J.

title: Psychophysiological responses in women reporting severe premenstrual symptoms.
abstract: 16 women attending a premenstrual tension clinic and 8 control women were tested in the pre- and postmenstrual phases with measures of heart rate (HR), skin conductance (SCO), and neck electromyogram (EMG). Measures were taken during rest, relaxation, an emotionally upsetting film, and performance of mental arithmetic and video game tasks. During relaxation, SCO level decreased to a greater extent in the premenstrual than in the postmenstrual phase, while EMG showed the reverse pattern. HR reactions to the mental and video game tasks were smaller in the premenstrual than in the postmenstrual phase for controls and for clinic attenders who showed only modest changes in symptom severity across the cycle, but not in attenders who showed marked premenstrual symptom increases. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Van den Akker, Olga; Steptoe, Andrew

title: Cognitive/attentional distraction in the control of conditioned nausea in pediatric cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.
abstract: Two studies were conducted to investigate the use of cognitive/attentional distraction (via commercially available video games) to control conditioned nausea in pediatric cancer patients receiving chemotherapy. The first study compared the nausea severity in children who played video games during chemotherapy-related procedures with that of control-group children who did not play video games. The second study used a combined ABAB withdrawal and repeated measures analysis of variance design that incorporated baseline and intervention assessments within a single session. In both studies, video game-playing resulted in significantly less nausea. The introduction and withdrawal of the opportunity to play video games produced significant changes (reduction and exacerbation, respectively) in nausea. Although video games also reduced self-reported anxiety, the effects were weaker than those for nausea. Pulse rate and systolic/diastolic blood pressure were not consistently affected. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology
authors: Redd, William H.; Jacobsen, Paul B.; Die-Trill, Maria; Dermatis, Helen; McEvoy, Maureen; Holland, Jimmie C.

title: Are cardiovascular responses to behavioral stressors a stable individual difference variable in childhood?
abstract: In Exp I, 18 8th-grade girls who had been in a study of the familial aggregation of cardiovascular responses to behavioral stress repeated the assessment protocol in the 9th grade. Results show that task-induced increases in diastolic blood pressure and heart rate during serial subtraction, mirror image tracing, and isometric handgrip tasks were reliable across test sessions. In Exp II, 18 5th-grade boys who had been in a previous experiment of cardiovascular responses during a videogame were tested in the 9th grade in the protocol used in Exp I. Results show that task-induced increases in diastolic blood pressure and heart rate during video games were related to task-induced increases during the other tasks over 3 yrs later. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Matthews, Karen A.; Rakaczky, Charles J.; Stoney, Catherine M.; Manuck, Stephen B.

title: Electrocardiographic effects of social stress on coronary-prone (Type A) individuals.
abstract: Observed 72 undergraduates selected for possession of either the Type A (coronary-prone) or Type B (coronary-resistant) behavior pattern as they interacted with a computer, while appearing to interact with a partner, in a formal competitive game of social strategy. Type A Ss exhibited greater impatience than Type B Ss. Computer analysis of the EKG revealed that social stimulation elicited larger ventricular electrophysiological responses (ST segment depression and reduction of T and R wave amplitudes) in Type A than in Type B Ss. Such changes are consistent with the assumption of greater cardiac sympathetic activity during the social interactions in the Type A Ss. (37 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Van Egeren, Lawrence F.; Fabrega, Horacio; Thornton, Dozier W.

title: Cardiovascular changes during social competition in a mixed-motive game.
abstract: 16 male and 16 female undergraduates played a mixed-motive game against a male confederate under either a 20 or an 80% cooperative strategy while cardiovascular responses were computer monitored. Females had larger heart rate responses than males during play under the competitive strategy, and the opposite was true during play under the cooperative strategy. Ss who were more competitive during the game, who scored higher on a coronary-prone (Type A) behavior scale, or who reported having an action orientation toward life stress tended to have larger heart rate responses during the game than did the remaining Ss. Results draw attention to the importance of covert autonomic responses for understanding overt behavioral choices in mixed-motive games and to the potential utility of this behavioral model for studying the role of psychosocial factors in psychosomatic illnesses. (21 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
authors: Van Egeren, Lawrence F.

title: Individual differences in heart rate and peripheral vascular responses to an extended aversive task.
abstract: Exposed 32 male undergraduates to a 1-hr shock avoidance procedure, with avoidance contingent on video game performance. Relationships among individual differences in heart rate (HR), forearm blood flow, forearm vascular resistance, and digital blood volume pulse responses were examined. Decreases in forearm vascular resistance were observed only among Ss with high and medium HR reactivity. As the session progressed, however, forearm vascular resistance responses of the medium HR reactors were sustained; those of high HR reactors habituated despite the fact that HR and forearm blood flow responses remained elevated. Implications of these results for an autoregulation theory of hypertension development are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Miller, Sydney B.; Ditto, Blaine

title: Microcomputer automated system for measuring systolic time intervals in response to exercise and a psychophysiological task.
abstract: Developed a microcomputer automated system for measuring systolic time intervals, using 38 male college students. Ss' EKG, phonocardiogram, and carotid pulse tracings were measured during baseline conditions and during either exercise on a bicycle ergometer or a video-game task. These measurements were recorded on both a traditional 3-channel EKG recorder and the computerized system. Both methods of recording systolic time intervals were independently scored by 2 different experimenters in order to assess interrater reliability of hand-scoring, intermethod reliability between hand-scoring vs computer-scoring, and interrater reliability of computer-scoring. Data indicate that the computerized method of scoring systolic time intervals was as reliable as the more traditional scoring of paper tracing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: VanDercar, David H.; Laperriere, Arthur R.; Shyu, Liang Y.; Ward, Michael F.; McCabe, Philip M.; Perry, Arlette; Schneiderman, Neil

title: Harassment, hostility, and Type A as determinants of cardiovascular reactivity during competition.
abstract: Assessed systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure, and heart rate (HR) during conditions of competition alone or in conjunction with goal blocking or harassment in 60 male undergraduates. Cardiovascular reactivity was examined as a function of conditions, Type A (coronary prone) or Type B (noncoronary prone) patterns, and various measures of anger/hostility. Ss completed the Jenkins Activity Survey—Form T before receiving the Type A structured interview; 2–5 wks later, Ss played a video game under conditions of competition control, goal blocking, or harassment. Harassment elicited significantly elevated SBP and HR changes relative to goal-blocking and control conditions. Type A's reliably exceeded Type B's in magnitude of SBP change during the harassment condition only. However, analyses correlating anger/hostility measures and cardiovascular reactivity indicated that only Ss scoring high on the Buss-Durkee Hostility-Guilt Inventory showed significantly elevated SBP reactivity as a function of Type A behavior pattern, rated hostility during the A-B interview, or outward expression of anger assessed by the Framingham Anger-In vs Anger-Out Scale. (46 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Diamond, Eric L.; Schneiderman, Neil; Schwartz, David; Smith, John C.; Vorp, Ronald; DeCarlo Pasin, Rosemary

title: Competitive two-person interactions of Type-A and Type-B individuals.
abstract: 40 undergraduates classified as either coronary-prone (Type A) or coronary-resistant (Type B) interacted in a mixed-motive game in pairs by pressing buttons that transmitted messages through a TV screen while an EKG and digital blood volume pulse were computer monitored. Ss were classified by scores on the Jenkins Activity Survey. Ss could cooperate, compete, punish, reward, or withdraw during each interaction and could send 1 of 55 messages communicating feelings, requests, and intentions between interactions. Paired Type A's interacted more competitively and aggressively than paired Type B's. There were no significant differences between Type A's and Type B's in heart rate or digital vasomotor response during the interpersonal game. The behavioral results confirm findings from an earlier experiment by the 1st author (see record [rid]1980-22844-001[/rid]). (11 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Van Egeren, Lawrence F.; Sniderman, Lawrence D.; Roggelin, M. Susan

title: Selective cardiovascular effects of stress and cigarette smoking in young women.
abstract: Used a 2 × 2 (smoke/no smoke × stress/no stress) factorial design to evaluate the impact of stress and smoking on the cardiovascular responses of 43 female undergraduates and college staff (mean age 20.7 yrs). The stressor was a video game. Results reveal that the combination of stress and cigarette smoking produced blood pressure and heart rate responses that were larger than the additive effects of smoking and stress taken separately. (36 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Dembroski, Theodore M.; MacDougall, James M.; Cardozo, Steven R.; Ireland, Susan K.; Krug-Fite, Janet

title: Personality factors, subject gender, and the effects of aggressive video games on aggression in adolescents.
abstract: Studied the relationship among personality factors, heart rate, and aggression after having played an aggressive video game in 28 male and 28 female 8th graders. It was found that for males, personality traits and heart rate were separately related to aggression. Personality characteristics similar to those of the Type A individual were related in a positive direction to heart rate in females. The content of the video games did not affect heart rate or postgame aggression, even though females displayed greater mean heart rate than males throughout the experiment. Results are discussed with regard to sex role stereotypes, content-related explanations of aggression, and Type A personality characteristics. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Winkel, Mark; Novak, Dawn M.; Hopson, Helen

title: Psychopathy and selective attention during performance of a complex perceptual-motor task.
abstract: Autonomic and electrocortical activity were recorded while 39 prison inmates (mean age 28.8 yrs) with high (Group H) and low (Group L) ratings of psychopathy were presented with a series of binaural tone pips, either by themselves (passive attention) or while video games were being played (selective attention). During selective attention, Ss were told that the tone pips were irrelevant to the primary task, the video games. The N100 component of the auditory EP was used as an index of attention paid to the tone pips, while performance on the video games was considered to be a reflection of attentiveness to the primary task. There were no group differences in N100 amplitude or latency during passive attention, supporting results from several previous studies. During selective attention Group H gave small N100 responses to the tone pips during each video game trial, including the first one, while Group L gave large N100 responses to the tone pips during the 1st trial, and small responses during later trials. Both groups performed equally well during the first few trials, but while the performance of Group L continued to improve, that of Group H deteriorated over the last few trials. Results are interpreted in terms of limited capacity models of attention and provide some support for the hypothesis that psychopaths allocate a relatively large proportion of their attentional resources to things of immediate interest, effectively ignoring other stimuli. (19 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Jutai, Jeffrey W.; Hare, Robert D.

title: Cardiovascular reactivity to psychological stress in aerobically trained versus untrained mild hypertensives and normotensives.
abstract: Compared cardiovascular reactivity to video game and mental arithmetic stressors among 3 groups of men (aged 21–63 yrs): (a) 11 aerobically trained mild hypertensives, (b) 7 untrained mild hypertensives, and (c) 9 untrained normotensives. Blood pressure (BP) reactivity of normotensives during the video game was generally similar to that of trained hypertensives but smaller than that of untrained hypertensives. There were no group differences in reactivity during mental arithmetic. Results indicate that aerobic training, which has been found to reduce resting BP in mild hypertensives, may also exert a favorable impact in reducing cardiovascular reactivity of hypertensives during some stressful situations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Perkins, Kenneth A.; Dubbert, Patricia M.; Martin, John E.; Faulstich, Michael E.; Harris, J. K.

title: Preferences for individual video games as a function of their emotional effects on players.
abstract: Used 3 independent dimensions of pleasure–displeasure, arousal–nonarousal, and dominance–submissiveness to assess emotional impacts of individual videogames and constructed a preference measure to evaluate attraction toward vs avoidance of specific games. In Study 1, 38 male and 20 female undergraduates rated the emotional impacts of 22 common arcade videogames, and 35 male and 18 female undergraduates rated their preferences for the same games. Findings indicate that the emotional impact of videogames was highly unpleasant, moderately arousing, and moderately dominance-inducing; thus, the predominant emotional response to these games was aggression, anger, or hostility. In Study 2, 69 male and 31 female patrons (mean age 18 yrs) of a university videogame arcade were recruited and assigned to play 2 games each and to report their reactions to each game immediately after playing. Results show that greater feelings of pleasure, and separately of arousal, while playing videogames resulted in higher preferences for the games and that greater dominance (significant only for males) also led to higher preferences. Implications for designs of home computer games or computer-based training and educational programs are discussed, and it is suggested that combinations of pleasant, arousing, and dominance-inducing features can enhance the attractiveness of games and programs to players and learners, respectively. (12 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Mehrabian, Albert; Wixen, Warren J.

title: Stress, smoking, and the cardiovascular system.
abstract: Reviews the literature on the cardiovascular effects of smoking and psychological stress in the light of epidemiological data and discusses mechanisms by which they may contribute to coronary heart disease. The integrated results of the studies suggest that psychological stressors (e.g., video games or mental arithmetic) can enhance adrenergic activity and sympathetic tone, setting into motion widespread physiological and biochemical perturbations. The use of nicotine in response to stress may exacerbate the potentially detrimental health consequences associated with chronic or excessive stimulation of the adrenomedullary system, particularly in susceptible or hyperreactive persons. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Pomerleau, Ovide F.; Pomerleau, Cynthia S.

title: Applications of a theory of automated adversarial planning to command and control.
abstract: Presents an overview of a theory of automated adversarial planning, derived from the enhancement and expansion of artificial intelligence (AI) techniques from the areas of automated planning and knowledge-based computer game playing. ARES (adversarial reasoning system), a computer program that can plan sequences of robot actions and compete in game environments, where adversities (including intelligent adversarial counterplanners) exist is discussed. It is suggested that AI planners have the potential for autonomously solving low-level planning problems such as those found in robotics applications and can form the basis of expert consultation systems for higher levels military planning problems involving command and control. (12 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, & Cybernetics
authors: Young, Paul R.; Lehner, Paul E.

title: The impact of videogame play on the emotional states of senior center participants.
abstract: In an experiment with 14 senior citizens, playing video games led to a decrease in pleasure, an increase in arousal, and no change in dominance, as measured by qualitative reactions and by responses to an emotional states scale. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Riddick, Carol C.; Drogin, Ellen B.; Spector, Sharon G.

title: Electrical reactive potential to events with positive and negative emotional coloring in patients with chronic depression.
abstract: Examined event-related potentials in 20 right-handed patients with chronic depression (aged 18–46 yrs) in response to emotional stimuli. Ss experienced a positive emotional stimulus (winning a serve in a video tennis game) or a negative stimulus (losing a serve). Cortical potentials were found to have specific features associated with positive and negative emotions. Findings suggest that, in chronic depression, the topography of cortical processes associated with emotional stimuli is impaired. This was reflected in the absence of any clear hemispheric dominance in the organization of emotional responses. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Kurnitskaya, I. V.; Dmitriev, A. S.

title: 'Underachievement' among markedly accelerated college students.
abstract: Investigated the personality, maturity, and underachievement of 14-yr-old college early entrance program students, using data on 12 undergraduates who had participated in an early entrance program and had earned grade point averages (GPAs) of less than 3.0, compared with 44 who had earned GPA's of 3.0 or above. Underachieving males (UAMs) appeared less psychologically mature and to suffer more internal conflict than achieving males, but underachieving females (UAFs) evidenced greater maturity than their counterparts. Asians had high average performance, reflecting an ethnic difference. Lower grades seemed to attend students, particularly males who were more adolescent than academic and females with absorbing extracurricular commitments. UAMs tended to be lost in juvenile fantasy and computer games or tangled in identity confusion and familial struggles for personal autonomy, whereas UAFs tended to be committed to varsity sports, precociously self-supporting, or physically unwell. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Janos, Paul M.; Sanfilippo, Susan M.; Robinson, Nancy M.

title: Complex decision making: A longitudinal study of process and performance.
abstract: Conducted 2 exploratory studies using a total of 15 undergraduate and 20 graduate students as Ss to investigate the process involved in a longitudinal decision-making (DM) task characterized by high S involvement, multiple interdependent decisions, and a changing decision environment. The longitudinal relationships between the DM processes that Ss used in the task and their task performance were also investigated. A computer-simulated, strategy-formulation game and simultaneous verbal protocols were used. It was found that a number of information-processing and information-evaluation thought processes were significantly related to game performance. Consistent with what is known about individual DM, the present results suggest that, for the task used in this study, individuals who engage in causal analysis perform better than those who did not. But those who focus on negative emotions, blindly repeat previously successful decisions, and engage in illogical thought processes perform more poorly than those who do not. (36 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
journal: Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes
authors: Schweiger, David M.; Anderson, Carl R.; Locke, Edwin A.

title: Heart rate feedback-assisted reduction in cardiovascular reactivity to a videogame challenge.
abstract: Investigated the reduction of cardiovascular responses to a videogame (VG) challenge, using heart rate (HR) feedback, in 20 undergraduate males. Ss received either (1) training with HR feedback (plus a score contingency in which VG performance was partly dependent on changes in HR) during VG presentations or (2) no feedback training during presentation of the same number of VGs. Ss receiving training exhibited lower HR responses and poorer VG performance during a posttraining assessment than no-feedback controls. Results support the hypothesis that HR feedback, combined with the score contingency and administered during a challenging VG, can be used to significantly reduce HR responsivity to that same challenge when presented without feedback. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Larkin, Kevin T.; Manuck, Stephen B.; Kasprowicz, Alfred L.

title: Sex differences in interpersonal conflict.
abstract: Compared male and female behavior in response to various forms of threats previously found to elicit different perceptual and behavioral reactions. 41 undergraduates played a fairly complex decision-making internation simulation game in a computer-controlled laboratory. Results indicate that deterrent threats were somewhat more likely to result in compliance than compellent threats. Although there were no gross differences between male and female response patterns, males were somewhat more likely to comply to a threat. Of the noncompliers, males were more likely to behave aggressively and attack the other. Evidence is presented which indicates that females respond to an emotion-evoking hostile situation by passively resisting or withdrawing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Johnson, Douglas F.; Mihal, William L.

title: Heart rate acceleration and its relationship to total serum cholesterol, triglycerides, and blood pressure reactivity in men with mild hypertension.
abstract: Investigated heart rate (HR) acceleration and its relationship to serum cholesterol, triglycerides, and blood pressure reactivity in 59 White males (aged 28–69 yrs) with unmedicated mild hypertension. Ss' cardiovascular responses were monitored during the Stroop Color and Word Test and the Pac Man videogame. High HR accelerators manifested greater systolic and diastolic blood pressure responses during behavioral challenge and higher levels of serum cholesterol and triglycerides than low HR accelerators. Findings suggest that HR acceleration may predict greater risk for stress related atherosclerosis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Jorgensen, Randall S.; Nash, John K.; Lasser, Norman L.; Hymowitz, Norman; Langer, Alan W.

title: Heart rate reactions to standard laboratory challenges and a naturalistic stressor.
abstract: Extreme high and low heart rate (HR) reactors were selected from a group of 24 young adults on the basis of responses to 2 laboratory stressors: a video game and a mental arithmetic task. HRs of the Ss were then recorded during a public-speaking competition. HR reactions to this more naturalistic stressor were generally in line with the laboratory-based designations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
authors: Turner, J. Rick; Carroll, Douglas; Dean, Sarah; Harris, Mike G.
